newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Kiwi dollar ends easier, seen struggling for grip.
newsitem.headline: Kiwi dollar ends easier, seen struggling for grip.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar closed a touch easier on Wednesday and was likely to continue to struggle in the medium term, dealers said.
The Kiwi ended at US$0.6900/07 from 0.6913/20 at the open. On its Trade-Weighted Index, it closed at 67.65 from 67.60.
"Overall we're still holding the US$0.6890-0.6900 level, but struggling to make any progress on the upside," said a bank chief dealer.
"That's against a backdrop of a firmer U.S. dollar and a firmer Aussie, so that's a negative and a positive for the Kiwi and sort of leaves us going nowhere quickly."
The Australian unit was closing in New Zealand at US$0.7655/60, up from Tuesday's 0.7645/50 close.
The dealer said there was still good interest in the Kiwi.
"We've seen continued interest out there to buy Kiwi against Aussie from U.S. accounts. Against that we've seen some Asian selling in the Kiwi.
"Overall it looks as though the Kiwi will struggle."
The market's focus was turning more and more towards June 27, when the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) delivers its Monetary Policy Statement.
"The overriding perception is clearly that the RBNZ will sanction an easing," the dealer said.
"I guess where people maybe differ slightly is the size of that easing."
The NZ dollar was seen trading a 0.6890-6915 range overnight.
